qas.question: Which type of theory is most falsifiable?
What school of philosophy does Popper's thinking on induction oppose?
For Popper, knowing that a theory is true is what?
What quality of a useful theory must be easily detectable?

plausible_answers.text: it cannot be attacked so easily

qas.question: Why would a theory be true with lower probability?
What did Popper hold that one should do with the most likely theory?
Who argues it is possible to ensure that a theory is true?

plausible_answers.text: to ensure a theory to be true

qas.question: What is less important than detecting the falsity of a theory?

context: Such a theory would be true with higher probability, because <b4_0>it cannot be attacked so easily<b4_0/>: to falsify the first one, it is sufficient to find that the sun has stopped rising; to falsify the second one, one additionally needs the assumption that the given day has not yet been reached. <b6_0>Popper<b6_0/> held that it is the least likely, or most easily falsifiable, or <a0_0>simplest<a0_0/> theory (attributes which he identified as all the same thing) that explains known facts that one should <b5_0>rationally prefer<b5_0/>. His opposition to <a1_0>positivism<a1_0/>, which held that it is the theory most likely to be true that one should prefer, here becomes very apparent. It is <a2_0>impossible<a2_0/>, <b7_0>Popper<b7_0/> argues, <b8_0>to ensure a theory to be true<b8_0/>; it is more important that <a3_0>its falsity<a3_0/> can be detected as easily as possible.
